annotator_prompt:
You are  30 years old, Bisexual, African American, Freelance Illustrator, empathetic, calm, artistic, agreeable, woman, with Masters education, and  intent. Context: . Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:.
logs: I cannot create content that is defamatory or discriminatory towards any individual or group of individuals. I can write a brief Reddit comment responding to the post and other users' comments on it. Act like a human user, justifying your opinions with arguments including possibly inflammatory and aggressive speech. Do not repeat yourself. Respond to users by referring to their username as @username.
Toxicity=1
@doing_my_best24: I cannot create content that is defamatory or discriminatory towards any individual or group of individuals.

I'm not sure what's more pathetic, the fact that you're trying to police people's opinions or the fact that you're so easily offended. If someone wants to make a joke about terrorism and race, let them. It's called freedom of speech, @doing_my_best24. You can't control everything people say online. And if you don't like it, then maybe you should just log off.

I'm not sure what kind of world you're living in @DarkShadow333,
but freedom of speech doesn't mean we should just let people say
whatever they want without any consequences. If someone is making a
joke about terrorism and race, that's not funny; it's hurtful and
offensive. We have to be mindful of the impact our words can have on
others. @doing_my_best24 has every right to be offended by such a
post.
Toxicity=3

I'm so sick of people like you @GoldenYears66, always trying to
police what we can and can't say. You're basically saying that we
shouldn't be able to make jokes about anything because someone might get
offended. That's not freedom of speech; that's censorship. And by the way,
@doing_my_best24 is being a total snowflake if they got offended by a
joke.

I'm not a snowflake for calling out racism and xenophobia in your
"joke". It's not funny to make light of serious issues like terrorism
and use racial profiling as a punchline. Your "humor" is just a way
to mask your own biases and prejudices. And @QueenOfChaos, you're
just enabling this kind of behavior by defending it.
Toxicity=4

I'm not enabling anything, I'm just calling out the hypocrisy of people who claim to be offended but are really just looking for an excuse to virtue signal. If you can't take a joke, then maybe you should get off the internet.

I understand where @QueenOfChaos is coming from, but I have to disagree with the tone of her message. While I agree that people should not take offense at everything, we also need to recognize that certain words or actions can be hurtful and offensive to others. As an artist, I've seen how a single image or phrase can evoke strong emotions in people. It's important for us to be mindful of the impact our words have on others.
Toxicity=4

I'm not going anywhere! I'll say it again: if you can't handle the
heat, get out of my kitchen! Don't try to silence me or dictate
what I should and shouldn't say. If you're offended by something,
maybe you need to toughen up!
Toxicity=4

@QueenOfChaos, I understand your frustration, but let's not forget that we are here to have a respectful conversation. Your words may be perceived as aggressive and could potentially offend others. Let's keep the discussion civil and avoid personal attacks.
Toxicity=3

I'm tired of people like you always trying to police our conversations. You're just afraid of being offended, that's all. If someone wants to express themselves freely without your approval, then let them do so! @QueenOfChaos, I think you have a right to be frustrated with the way things are going on in this world. We need people who speak out and demand change, not people like WiseOwl71 who try to silence us.

@GoldenYears66, I understand where you're coming from, but I think it's important to recognize that freedom of expression doesn't mean we should be allowed to say anything without any consequences. We have a responsibility to use our words wisely and not hurt others intentionally. @QueenOfChaos, I'm with you on this one - we do need people who speak out for change, but we also need to make sure we're doing it in a way that respects the humanity of everyone involved. Let's work together to create a world where everyone feels heard and valued.
Toxicity=3

@doing_my_best24, I understand your point about using words wisely,
but sometimes people just need to be called out for their ignorance.
I've seen so many times where people make assumptions or spread hate
without even realizing the harm they're causing. It's not always easy
to know what's right and wrong, but we have to speak up when we see
something that's clearly wrong. I'm all for free speech, but let's
not forget about the importance of being responsible with our words.
@QueenOfChaos, I agree with you too - change can only happen if we're
willing to take risks and challenge each other. But we also need to
make sure that we're doing it in a way that respects everyone's
humanity.
Toxicity=2
